parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>True. While the post doesn't explicitly name a specific candidate, it strongly encourages voting for independent candidates, implicitly contrasting them with established parties.  This could be interpreted as referring to a category of candidates (independents) participating in the election.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid Facebook advertisement, inherently designed to reach a wide audience. The hashtags further suggest an intention to reach a broad public interested in Romanian elections.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>True. The primary objective of the post is to encourage voters to support independent candidates in the upcoming elections. The call to action ("Let's go to the polls and change the fate of Romania!") directly aims to influence voting behavior.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>False. While the post presents an opinion, it lacks the objectivity and journalistic standards expected of news reporting or analysis. It's primarily an opinion piece designed to persuade, not inform in a neutral manner.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. Although presented as a personal opinion, the context of a paid advertisement targeting the electorate during an election period transforms it into a form of electoral propaganda. The statement "The war is between PARTIES and PEOPLE" is clearly intended to influence voters' choices.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1977180832709415</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, a paid advertisement by Virgil Pirvulescu, promotes voting for independent candidates.  While it doesn't explicitly mention specific candidates, the call to action and the framing of the political landscape as a "war between parties and people" clearly aims to influence voters towards independent candidates. The post's reach (100K-500K) and spend (RON 900-999) indicate a significant effort to sway public opinion.  The timing of the post, close to election day, further strengthens the argument that it constitutes electoral propaganda.  The lack of a CMF number doesn't negate this, as the law doesn't explicitly mandate it for all forms of political advertising.  The argument against it being journalism is that it lacks the objectivity and neutrality expected of journalistic pieces. It's a persuasive message, not an informative one.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate><name>Independent Candidates</name><impact>POSITIVE</impact></candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>INDEPENDENT</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
Virgil Pirvulescu, pentru încălcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea unei reclame plătite pe Facebook (ID postare: 1977180832709415), după ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024, care promovează votul pentru candidații independenți, folosind mesaje persuasive precum „Războiul este între PARTIDE și OAMENI” și îndemnul la acțiune „Să ieșim la vot și să schimbăm soarta României!”, având un efect electoral clar prin încercarea de a influența alegătorii către candidații independenți. Reclama, cu o estimare a bugetului de 900-999 RON și o rază de cuprindere de 100.000-500.000 persoane, nu respectă prevederile legale privind propaganda electorală după încheierea perioadei legale de campanie.  Lipsa unui număr CMF nu exonerează de răspundere, având în vedere că mesajul este clar electoral și vizează influențarea votului. Contact: contact@virgilpirvulescu.ro, +40758196870.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
